sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Review

NEWSWATCH June 21, 2012

LIONS KILLED NEAR NAIROBI

Yesterday morning, six lions were killed in Kitengela, just 15 kilometers south of Nairobi National Park. The killings have sent shock waves across Kenya and around the world.

Nairobi National Park is one of the most visited protected areas in Africa. The park is just a ten-minute ride from downtown Nairobi, and is therefore a popular tourist destination. However, the park’s location close to residential areas and farmlands has led to conflicts between farmers and lions.

Part of the problem is that the park is fenced only to the east, north, and west—the sides closest to the city. Consequently, zebras and other wild animals are able to migrate across the park’s unfenced southern border. Lions and other predators follow them. Some cross into residential areas such as Kitengela, and kill farmers’ livestock. As a result, the farmers become angry and kill the big cats. This seems to be the cause of the latest killings.

The Kenyan government says it will find and arrest the killers of the Kitengela Six. Local community leaders, however, argue that the government does not really take seriously the farmers’ livestock losses. Because of this conflict, says conservationist Paula Kahumbu, Kenya must find “a lasting solution that will enable people to benefit from living lions.”

Kahumbu and other conservationists are afraid for the lions’ future. For much of the past decade, Kenya has been losing 100 lions a year. This is largely due to habitat loss, but also because of lion killings. Unless there is a way to solve the human–lion conflict, Kenya’s lions could disappear in 20 years.

items.q: Many tourists visit Nairobi National Park.
There is a fence around all four sides of the park.
When zebras and other animals leave the park, lions follow them.
Lions killed six farmers near Kitengela.
Local leaders from Kitengela believe that the Kenyan government doesn’t understand how serious the problem is.
According to the article, Paula Kahumbu believes she has found a solution to the lion-farmer problem.
Over the last 10 years, 100 lions have been killed in Kenya.
Conservationists say that lions could completely disappear from Kenya in 20 years.

sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Extension



The Whooping Crane

The beautiful whooping crane is the tallest bird in North America, standing about 5 feet (1.5 meters) tall. The western population lives in north-western Canada during the summer, and migrates to coastal Texas for the winter months. The eastern population spends its summers in Wisconsin and winters in Florida.

When Europeans first came to the continent of North America, it is estimated that there were about 10,000 whooping cranes. However, during the 19th century, people hunted the crane and gathered their eggs. By 1870, the population was down to around 1,400 birds. The species nearly disappeared in the mid-twentieth century and a 1941 count found only 16 living adults.

But since then, these birds have taken a step back from extinction. Captive breeding programs and successful re-introduction programs have raised the number of birds to nearly 600, including some 200 or so in captivity1. Their biggest threat is loss of feeding grounds. The areas where the birds spend their winter are protected, but the freshwater wetlands where they feed are in some cases almost completely dry due to drought2.

One of the measures used to boost the population of the cranes is particularly innovative. It is called costume-rearing3. Handlers wear hand puppets4 on their arm to feed and interact with the chicks5 that are born in captivity. Sometimes they even wear full-length crane costumes to hide the human form. Handlers6 use this costume-rearing technique to make sure the chicks are familiar with other whooping cranes when they are finally ready to be released back into the wild.

The whooping crane remains an endangered species, but their growing numbers are a success story for conservationists7.

1 captivity: n. the condition of being kept in a place (such as a zoo or a prison) and not being able to leave
2 drought: n. a long-lasting lack of rainfall
3 costume-rearing: a costume is clothing worn to hide one’s identity; rearing means taking care of animals or young children.
4 hand puppet: a doll that is controlled by putting one’s hand in it
5  chicks: n. baby birds
6 handlers: n. people who feed and care for animals (in a zoo, for example)
7 conservationists: n. people who want to protect animals and other aspects of nature

items.q: Where do birds that spend their summers in Canada go in the winter? a. Florida b. Wisconsin c. Texas
When was the population of whooping cranes at its lowest point? a. In the 1870’s. b. In the 1940’s. c. In the last few years.
What is the biggest danger now threatening whooping cranes? a. hunting b. development of their habitat c. lack of water
The bolded word they in paragraph 4 refers to . . . a. whooping cranes b. handlers c. hand puppets

Which of the following statements is NOT true of costume-rearing? a. Handlers sometimes wear costumes to look like the birds. b. Handlers use hand puppets to give food to the baby birds. c. Handlers dress the birds in special clothes to keep them warm.
DIRECTIONS: Decide if this sentence is a main idea (M) or detail (D) in the article. The whooping crane is about 1.5 meters tall.
DIRECTIONS: Decide if this sentence is a main idea (M) or detail (D) in the article. Whooping cranes almost disappeared completely, but now the population is growing.
DIRECTIONS: Decide if this sentence is a main idea (M) or detail (D) in the article. Costume-rearing has helped the whooping crane survive.
DIRECTIONS: Decide if this sentence is a main idea (M) or detail (D) in the article. The hand puppets and costumes worn by handlers match the color and shape of the adult whooping cranes.
DIRECTIONS: Decide if this sentence is a main idea (M) or detail (D) in the article. There are two populations of whooping cranes which follow different migration paths.

Reading Skills

Sentences about Tigers

A. Tigers are disappearing from India due to the loss of their habitat.

B. The animals that tigers hunted in the past are also disappearing. Therefore, tigers sometimes kill local people’s livestock.

C. It is illegal to kill tigers. Wild tigers are still hunted, however, because their bones, whiskers, and other body parts can be sold as medicines for a lot of money.

D. The huge demand for medicines made from tigers has led to an increase in the killing of tigers.

items.q: Read sentence A above. Write the word or phrase that shows cause and effect. _______________
Read sentence B above. Write the word or phrase that shows cause and effect. _______________
Read sentence C above. Write the word or phrase that shows cause and effect. _______________
Read sentence D above. Write the word or phrase that shows cause and effect. _______________
Identify the following sentence as a Cause or an Effect according to the information in sentences A–D. Sentence A - Much of tigers’ habitat has disappeared. _____________
Identify the following sentence as a Cause or an Effect according to the information in sentences A–D. Sentence B - Tigers sometimes hunt livestock rather than wild animals. _____________
Identify the following sentence as a Cause or an Effect according to the information in sentences A–D. Sentence C - Tigers’ body parts are used as medicine. _______________
Identify the following sentence as a Cause or an Effect according to the information in sentences A–D. Sentence D - The number of tigers that have been killed has increased rapidly. _______________

sections.instructions: DIRECTIONS: Read the following excerpt from Richard Turere’s 2013 TED Talk and answer the questions.
sections.passage:
TED Talk Comprehension



Richard Turere—My Invention That Made Peace With Lions

Part 1

This is where I live. I live in Kenya, at the south parts of the Nairobi National Park. Those are my dad’s cows at the back, and behind the cows, that’s the Nairobi National Park. Nairobi National Park is not fenced in the south widely, which means wild animals like zebras migrate out of the park freely. So predators like lions follow them, and this is what they do. They kill our livestock. This is one of the cows which was killed at night, and I just woke up in the morning and I found it dead, and I felt so bad, because it was the only bull we had. . . .

So I had to find a way of solving this problem. And the first idea I got was to use fire, because I thought lions were scared of fire. But I came to realize that that didn’t really help, because it was even helping the lions to see through the cowshed1. So I didn’t give up. I continued.

And a second idea I got was to use a scarecrow2. I was trying to trick the lions [into thinking] that I was standing near the cowshed. But lions are very clever. They will come the first day and they see the scarecrow, and they go back, but the second day, they’ll come and they say, this thing is not moving here, it’s always here. So he jumps in and kills the animals.

So one night, I was walking around the cowshed with a torch, and that day, the lions didn’t come. And I discovered that lions are afraid of a moving light. So I had an idea.

Part 2

Since I was a small boy, I used to work in my room for the whole day, and I even took apart my mom’s new radio, and that day she almost killed me, but I learned a lot about electronics. So I got an old car battery, [and] an indicator box. It’s a small device found in a motorcycle, and it helps motorists when they want to turn right or left. It blinks. And I got a switch where I can switch on the lights, on and off. And that’s a small torch from a broken flashlight.

So I set up everything. As you can see, the solar panel3 charges the battery, and the battery supplies the power to the small indicator box. I call it a transformer. And the indicator box makes the lights flash. As you can see, the bulbs face outside, because that’s where the lions come from. And that’s how it looks to lions when they come at night. The lights flash and trick the lions into thinking I was walking around the cowshed, but I was sleeping in my bed.

1 cowshed: n. a farm building used to house cows
2 scarecrow: n. an object that looks like a person meant to scare birds and other animals away from crops or livestock
3 solar panel: n. a device that uses sunlight to make electricity

items.q: Richard Turere felt bad when he found the dead cow because . . .
options: it was the only male cow his family owned.
the cow was a present to him from his father.

items.q: According to Richard Turere, the use of fire . . .
Why were the lions not afraid of the scarecrow?
options: Because it didn’t look like a real person.

items.q: Richard Turere used his mother’s radio to . . .
options: scare away lions with loud noise.
get a part that he needed for his invention.

items.q: Which of the following is NOT a part used in Richard Turere’s invention?
options: an engine from an old motorcycle
a switch to control the lights

items.q: Richard Turere’s invention makes the lions think that . . .
options: there are no cows in the cowshed.
there is a person in the cowshed.
they will receive an electrical shock.
